title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate consumer surplus as $12 and/or does not show the work.

Consumer Surplus = Marginal Benefit−Price =   $14−$2 = $12 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@692A@

The response calculates consumer surplus as $12 and shows the work.

Consumer Surplus = Marginal Benefit−Price =   $14−$2 = $12 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@692A@

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify that 1 bandana and 4 units of Good G will maximize Maria’s total benefit given her weekly income of $9 and/or does not explain that for the last unit of each good consumed the ratio of the marginal benefit to the price of Good G (10) is equal to the ratio of the marginal benefit to the price of bandanas (10), or

M B Bandana Pric e Bandana = M B Good G Pric e Good G MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5F28@

$10 $1 = $20 $2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@41C0@

10=10 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D0C@

The response identifies that that 1 bandana and 4 units of Good G will maximize Maria’s total benefit given her weekly income of $9 and explains that for the last unit of each good consumed the ratio of the marginal benefit to the price of Good G (10) is equal to the ratio of the marginal benefit to the price of bandanas (10), or

M B Bandana Pric e Bandana = M B Good G Pric e Good G MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5F28@

$10 $1 = $20 $2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@41C0@

10=10 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D0C@

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that yes, Maria would be able to buy 3 bandanas and 4 units of Good G and/or does not explain that her total expenditures would be $11 (=$3×1+$2×4) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@44DB@ , which is less than her weekly income of $12.

The response states that yes, Maria would be able to buy 3 bandanas and 4 units of Good G and explains that her total expenditures would be $11 (=$3×1+$2×4) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@44DB@ , which is less than her weekly income of $12.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify Good G and Good R as complements and/or does not explain that the cross-price elasticity of demand is negative because a 5% decrease in the price of Good G led to a 4% increase in the demand for Good R.

The response identifies Good G and Good R as complements and explains that the cross-price elasticity of demand is negative because a 5% decrease in the price of Good G led to a 4% increase in the demand for Good R.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the quantity of bandanas that will maximize Maria’s total benefit will increase and/or does not explain that a decrease in the price of an input to production will increase the supply of bandanas, which will decrease the price of bandanas and increase the marginal benefit per dollar spent for each additional unit consumed.

The response states that the quantity of bandanas that will maximize Maria’s total benefit will increase and explains that a decrease in the price of an input to production will increase the supply of bandanas, which will decrease the price of bandanas and increase the marginal benefit per dollar spent for each additional unit consumed.
